required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on September 19, 2022
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Cardiometabolic Risk and Obesity in Adolescents With Down Syndrome

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this research study is to determine which measures best capture cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk and type 2 diabetes (T2DM) risk in children and adolescents with Down syndrome (DS).
We hypothesize that DS is associated with worse cardiometabolic risk factors for a given body mass index compared to controls. This difference arises at least in part, from increased fat tissue.

detailed_description.textblock:
DS affects 1 per 800 births and is one of the most common causes of developmental disability in the US. Life expectancy for Down syndrome has increased significantly: estimated median survival in the US in 1997 was 49 years. DS is associated with an increased risk for obesity, with an estimated prevalence of 47-48% in adults and 30-50% in children with DS. Adolescents with DS are more likely to have increased adiposity compared to unaffected peers and may be at increased risk for obesity-related co-morbidities, such as type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. How one defines obesity in DS is not clear. Individuals with DS have short stature and possibly increased adiposity, and the body mass index (BMI) used to define obesity for otherwise healthy populations may not accurately depict body fatness or capture cardiometabolic risk in DS.
Congenital heart disease (CHD) affects approximately 50% of individuals with DS; the National Institutes of Health Heart Lung and Blood Institute (NHLBI) Working Group on Obesity and Other Cardiovascular Risk Factors in Congenital Heart Disease highlighted the high prevalence of obesity in the setting of CHD, and called for studies to identify obesity measures that are more sensitive than BMI as well as studies of CVD risk prevention. Unfortunately, clinicians caring for obese adolescents with DS with or without CHD have little scientific evidence upon which to base guidance regarding cardiometabolic risk (CMR): data regarding CVD risk and prevalence of pre-diabetes and T2DM in obese adolescents with DS are lacking.
The measure of body fatness which best predicts CMR in DS is not known. We plan to compare BMI and other measures of body fatness in healthy controls and adolescents with DS to determine which measures best capture CVD and/or T2DM risk. These data will equip medical providers with the tools to better assess risk, initiate prevention measures, and guide screening in adolescents with DS.

primary_outcome.description: Non-HDL cholesterol measured via fasting blood draw
Lipoprotein subclass particle analysis run on samples from fasting blood drawn Study Visit 1.
Lipoprotein subclass particle analysis run on samples from fasting blood drawn Study Visit 1.
Insulin Resistance (HOMA-IR) was calculated as [fasting insulin (uIU/mL) x fasting glycemia (mmol/L)]/22.5
hs-CRP, PAI-1, and IL-6 run on samples from fasting blood drawn Study Visit 1.

Impaired fasting glucose (IFG) was defined as fasting glucose ≥ 100 mg/dl. Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) was defined as 2-hour glucose 140-199 mg/dl measured as part of an oral glucose tolerance test.
Adiposity measured by Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry
Adiposity measured by Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry

Cardiac end organ injury assessed by echocardiography. Left Ventricular Mass (LVM) was measured by area/length method using the apical four-chamber and parasternal short-axis views. LVM was calculated as LV area × LV length × 1.05 × 5/6.
Cardiac end organ injury assessed by Pulse Wave Velocity (PWV)

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Related Quality of Life - PedsQL
secondary_outcome.description: Caregiver-perception of his/her child's health-related QOL was assessed with the use of the parent-proxy report of the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) Version 4.0. Sub-scale scores are converted to a 0-100 scale so that greater scores indicate better QOL. Scale scores are computed as the sum of the items divided by the number of items answered (this accounts for missing data). If more than 50% of the items in the scale are missing, the scale score is not computed. The Physical Health Summary Score (8 items) is the same as the Physical Functioning Scale. To create the Psychosocial Health Summary Score (15 items), the mean is computed as the sum of the items divided by the number of items answered in the Emotional, Social, and School Functioning Scales.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Related Quality of Life - IWQOL
secondary_outcome.description: Parent perception of the effects of weight on his/her child's QOL was assessed with a caregiver-proxy version of the Impact of Weight on Quality of Life - Kids (IWQOL-Kids) questionnaire. The IWQOL-Kids is a validated, 27-item, self-report measure of weight-related QOL for youth ages 11-19 years. It yields 4 subscales (Physical Comfort, Body Esteem, Social Life, and Family Relations) and a Total score, which have strong psychometric properties, discriminate among weight status groups, and are responsive to weight change. Scaled scores are standardized and range from 0 to 100, with greater scores representing better weight-related QOL.

arm_group.description: No intervention occurred as this was a cross sectional observational study.
No intervention occurred as this was a cross sectional observational study.

study_pop.textblock: Participants will be recruited from primary care and speciality clinics, Trisomy 21 events, T21 interest groups, and referrals.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Both groups: Ages 10 - 20
- Both groups: Parental/guardian permission (informed consent) and if appropriate, child assent.
- Down syndrome group only: diagnosis of Down syndrome
Exclusion Criteria (both groups):
- Major organ system illness (such as leukemia), except for type 2 Diabetes
- Cyanotic congenital heart disease and/or pulmonary hypertension
- Medically unstable congenital heart disease
- Pregnancy
- Genetic syndrome known to affect glucose tolerance
- Familial hypercholesterolemia
- Currently treated with medications known to affect insulin sensitivity (other than diabetes agents in participants with type 2 diabetes)

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Down Syndrome
group.description: 154 participants ages 10-20 years old. No intervention occurred as this is a cross-sectional observational study.

group.title: Control
group.description: 103 age-, sex-, race-, ethnicity-, and BMI percentile-matched control subjects. No intervention occurred as this is a cross-sectional observational study.

baseline.population: Participants from the Down syndrome and control groups were matched on BMI percentile, age, race, ethnicity, and sex.

group.title: Down Syndrome
group.description: Our goal is to enroll 155 subjects with Down syndrome, and to compare their data to our control group.

group.title: Control
group.description: Our goal is to enroll 105 typically developing controls, who are matched to the Down syndrome group by age, sex, race, ethnicity, and BMI-z score.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: BMI Percentile
measure.description: Height & weight were measured and entered into the online CDC BMI Calculator for children and teens to determine percentile.

outcome.title: Abnormal Glucose Tolerance
outcome.description: Impaired fasting glucose (IFG) was defined as fasting glucose ≥ 100 mg/dl. Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) was defined as 2-hour glucose 140-199 mg/dl measured as part of an oral glucose tolerance test.
outcome.population: Participants completed an oral glucose tolerance test if they were in the overweight or obese categories: DS n=96, Control n=64.

outcome.title: Left Ventricular Mass
outcome.description: Cardiac end organ injury assessed by echocardiography. Left Ventricular Mass (LVM) was measured by area/length method using the apical four-chamber and parasternal short-axis views. LVM was calculated as LV area × LV length × 1.05 × 5/6.
outcome.population: LVM was available in 136 adolescents with DS (60M/76F) and 101nonDS controls (41M/60F).

outcome.title: Health Related Quality of Life - PedsQL
outcome.description: Caregiver-perception of his/her child's health-related QOL was assessed with the use of the parent-proxy report of the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) Version 4.0. Sub-scale scores are converted to a 0-100 scale so that greater scores indicate better QOL. Scale scores are computed as the sum of the items divided by the number of items answered (this accounts for missing data). If more than 50% of the items in the scale are missing, the scale score is not computed. The Physical Health Summary Score (8 items) is the same as the Physical Functioning Scale. To create the Psychosocial Health Summary Score (15 items), the mean is computed as the sum of the items divided by the number of items answered in the Emotional, Social, and School Functioning Scales.

measure.title: Health Related Quality of Life - PedsQL
measure.description: Caregiver-perception of his/her child's health-related QOL was assessed with the use of the parent-proxy report of the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) Version 4.0. Sub-scale scores are converted to a 0-100 scale so that greater scores indicate better QOL. Scale scores are computed as the sum of the items divided by the number of items answered (this accounts for missing data). If more than 50% of the items in the scale are missing, the scale score is not computed. The Physical Health Summary Score (8 items) is the same as the Physical Functioning Scale. To create the Psychosocial Health Summary Score (15 items), the mean is computed as the sum of the items divided by the number of items answered in the Emotional, Social, and School Functioning Scales.

outcome.title: Health Related Quality of Life - IWQOL
outcome.description: Parent perception of the effects of weight on his/her child's QOL was assessed with a caregiver-proxy version of the Impact of Weight on Quality of Life - Kids (IWQOL-Kids) questionnaire. The IWQOL-Kids is a validated, 27-item, self-report measure of weight-related QOL for youth ages 11-19 years. It yields 4 subscales (Physical Comfort, Body Esteem, Social Life, and Family Relations) and a Total score, which have strong psychometric properties, discriminate among weight status groups, and are responsive to weight change. Scaled scores are standardized and range from 0 to 100, with greater scores representing better weight-related QOL.

measure.title: Health Related Quality of Life - IWQOL
measure.description: Parent perception of the effects of weight on his/her child's QOL was assessed with a caregiver-proxy version of the Impact of Weight on Quality of Life - Kids (IWQOL-Kids) questionnaire. The IWQOL-Kids is a validated, 27-item, self-report measure of weight-related QOL for youth ages 11-19 years. It yields 4 subscales (Physical Comfort, Body Esteem, Social Life, and Family Relations) and a Total score, which have strong psychometric properties, discriminate among weight status groups, and are responsive to weight change. Scaled scores are standardized and range from 0 to 100, with greater scores representing better weight-related QOL.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse Events are monitored throughout participants' roughly 6 hour study visit, and for the 2 weeks following study visit while participants are wearing accelerator armbands and completing dietary recalls at home.

group.title: Down Syndrome
group.description: Our goal is to enroll 155 subjects with Down syndrome, and to compare their data to our control group.

group.title: Control
group.description: Our goal is to enroll 105 typically developing controls, who are matched to the Down syndrome group by age, sex, race, ethnicity, and BMI-z score.

event.description: Hypoglycemia occurring during oral glucose tolerance test. Test prematurely stopped so that participant could ingest food.
Vomiting in reaction to glucola ingestion associated with oral glucose tolerance test.
Fainting in reaction to blood draw.
Skin irritation due to physical activity armband wear. If irritation occurred armband wear was discontinued.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
